How to use

Animal Facts API can be used with any kind of project (school, personal, etc). You can use examples below to check how Animal Facts API works and feel free to enjoy it in your awesome projects!

These are the 4 main endpoints available in Animal facts api:

GET: https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/all-facts.json
GET: https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/animal-fact/4.json
GET: https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/random-fact.json
GET: https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/search-animal.json

Note: Use the GET HTTP methods to get a response.

Fetching 'all' facts


Endpoint:
https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/all-facts.json


Example code:

      
        const url = 'https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/all-facts.json';

        fetch(url).then((response)=>{
          return response.json();
        }).then(data=>{
          console.log(data);
        }).catch(function(error) {
          console.log(error);
        });
      
      
      
        $.ajax({
          url:'https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/all-facts.json',
          type:'GET',
          dataType:'json',
          success: function(response) {
            console.log(response);
          },
          error: function(error) {
            console.log(error);
          },
        });
      
      
      
        $ pip install requests # if you don't have requests installed already

        import requests

        res = requests.get('https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/all-facts.json')

        response = res.json()

        print(response)

Example response:

      
        {
          "id": 1,
          "animal": "Pistol Shrimp",
          "image_url": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cb/Alpheus_distinguendus.jpg",
          "setup": "The loudest animal in the world is a mere 2cm long, prawn.",
          "delivery": "The Pistol Shrimp is capable of snapping it’s claw shut so rapidly, that it creates a bubble which collapses to produce a sonic blast, louder than a Corncode’s sonic boom. The shock wave can reach 230 decibels, louder than the sound of a gunshot. The imploding bubble for split seconds also generates temperates of 4,400C, nearly as hot as the sun, killing it’s prey."
        },

        {
          "id": 2,
          "animal": "Flamingo",
          "image_url": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/38/Flamingos_Laguna_Colorada.jpg",
          "setup": "Flamingos are not pink.",
          "delivery": "They are born grey, their diet of brine shrimp and blue green algae contains a natural pink dye called canthaxanthin that makes their feathers pink. Flamingos in zoos often lost their coloring, until zoo keepers supplemented their diets."
        },

        {
          "id": 3,
          "animal": "Otter",
          "image_url": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d3/Fischotter,_Lutra_Lutra.JPG",
          "setup": "Otters “hold hands” while sleeping.",
          "delivery": "Otters hold hands while sleeping, so they don’t float away from each other. And it looks super-cute."
        },

        {
          "id": 4,
          "animal": "Hummingbird",
          "image_url": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7c/Trinidad_and_Tobago_hummingbirds_composite.jpg",
          "setup": "Hummingbirds are the only known birds that can also fly backwards.",
          "delivery": "They often do this when retreating away from flowers."
        },

        {
          "id": 5,
          "animal": "Dolphin",
          "image_url": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/10/Tursiops_truncatus_01.jpg",
          "setup": "Dolphins use toxic pufferfish to ‘get high’.",
          "delivery": "Dolphins deliberately handle pufferfish causing them to release toxins as a defense mechanism. These toxins can be deadly in high doses, but also have a narcotic effect – and are a powerful hallucinogenic, which dolphins appear to enjoy. A documentary witnessed them passing around pufferfish in a pod, before floating just underneath the water’s surface, apparently ‘mesmerized by their own reflections’ afterwards."
        },

        {
          ...more data here..
        }

Fetching an animals fact based on its 'id' in the database facts


Endpoint:
https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/animal-fact/4.json


Example code:

      
        const url = 'https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/animal-fact/4.json';

        fetch(url).then((response)=>{
          return response.json();
        }).then(data=>{
          console.log(data);
        }).catch(function(error) {
          console.log(error);
        });
      
      
      
        $.ajax({
          url:'https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/animal-fact/4.json',
          type:'GET',
          dataType:'json',
          success: function(response) {
            console.log(response);
          },
          error: function(error) {
            console.log(error);
          },
        });
      
      
      
        $ pip install requests # if you don't have requests installed already

        import requests

        res = requests.get('https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/animal-fact/4.json')

        response = res.json()

        print(response)

Example response:

      
        {
          "id": 4,
          "animal": "Hummingbird",
          "image_url": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7c/Trinidad_and_Tobago_hummingbirds_composite.jpg",
          "setup": "Hummingbirds are the only known birds that can also fly backwards.",
          "delivery": "They often do this when retreating away from flowers."
        }

Fetching a random fact


Endpoint:
https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/random-fact.json


Example code:

      
        const url = 'https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/random-fact.json';

        fetch(url).then((response)=>{
          return response.json();
        }).then(data=>{
          console.log(data);
        }).catch(function(error) {
          console.log(error);
        });
      
      
      
        $.ajax({
          url:'https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/random-fact.json',
          type:'GET',
          dataType:'json',
          success: function(response) {
            console.log(response);
          },
          error: function(error) {
            console.log(error);
          },
        });
      
      
      
        $ pip install requests # if you don't have requests installed already

        import requests

        res = requests.get('https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/random-fact.json')

        response = res.json()

        print(response)

Example response:

      
        {
          "id": 2,
          "animal": "Flamingo",
          "image_url": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/38/Flamingos_Laguna_Colorada.jpg",
          "setup": "Flamingos are not pink.",
          "delivery": "They are born grey, their diet of brine shrimp and blue green algae contains a natural pink dye called canthaxanthin that makes their feathers pink. Flamingos in zoos often lost their coloring, until zoo keepers supplemented their diets."
        }

Fetching a fact based on a 'search' query


Endpoint:
https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/search-animal.json?q=your_query


Example code:

      
        const url = 'https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/search-animal.json?q=otter';

        fetch(url).then((response)=>{
          return response.json();
        }).then(data=>{
          console.log(data);
        }).catch(function(error) {
          console.log(error);
        });
      
      
      
        $.ajax({
          url:'https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/search-animal.json?q=otter',
          type:'GET',
          dataType:'json',
          success: function(response) {
            console.log(response);
          },
          error: function(error) {
            console.log(error);
          },
        });
      
      
      
        $ pip install requests # if you don't have requests installed already

        import requests

        res = requests.get('https://animalfactsapi.herokuapp.com/api-v1/search-animal.json?q=otter')

        response = res.json()

        print(response)

Example response:

      
        {
          "id": 3,
          "animal": "Otter",
          "image_url": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d3/Fischotter,_Lutra_Lutra.JPG",
          "setup": "Otters “hold hands” while sleeping.",
          "delivery": "Otters hold hands while sleeping, so they don’t float away from each other. And it looks super-cute."
        }
